nodes.text: An input-aware selective instruction duplication framework can significantly mitigate silent data corruption (SDC) coverage loss across diverse runtime inputs while remaining lightweight and practical for HPC applications

Existing selective instruction duplication (SID) methods derive instruction vulnerability from a single default reference input and assume input-invariant SDC propagation, causing substantial SDC coverage loss when inputs vary
Protego performs a one-time offline SDC vulnerability-guided input search (500 inputs) to discover diverse inputs that reveal distinct SID protection variants

Protego clusters explored inputs into a small number of input groups by minimizing maximum allowable SDC coverage loss within groups and selects a representative input and its SID-protected executable per group (10% threshold chosen)

At runtime Protego extracts five lightweight features from input arguments, uses a trained MLP regressor to predict overall SDC vulnerability, maps to the closest input group, and returns the precomputed representative SID-protected executable without runtime fault injection or dynamic profiling

Empirical evaluation across inputs for 10 HPC applications shows existing static SID plans can underprotect critical regions and reduce SDC coverage substantially (examples: Pathfinder coverage drop from 43% to 29 under different input)
The guided search uses genetic-style mutations and crossovers to evolve inputs and prioritizes new inputs whose instruction-level SDC profiles deviate most from already observed profiles
For each explored input Protego runs instruction-level fault injection at LLVM IR to measure SDC probabilities and compute candidate scores; the search terminates after collecting 500 unique inputs
Grouping analysis shows few input groups suffice to approximate the spectrum of SID variants; a 10% maximum allowable SDC coverage loss yields consistently small group counts across applications

Feature selection transforms input arguments (polynomial, product, log, etc.) and selects top 5 features by mutual information; an MLP with layers 512-256-128-64-32 trained with Adam predicts overall SDC vulnerability with low mean absolute error
Protego avoids expensive online fault injection and dynamic tracing by using input-argument derived features as proxies for execution-induced SDC vulnerability shifts
The trained MLP achieved low MAE in estimating overall SDC rate across the 10 applications (example MAE values range from 0.03 to 6.14 percent across applications), enabling accurate group mapping

Protego reduces average mean SDC coverage loss across 10 applications from 21% (baseline static SID) to 10% at runtime inputs (averaged over protection overheads), and provides much lower per-application mean losses shown in experiments

Protego provides fast runtime selection (average ~0.05 seconds per input) and achieves roughly 100x speedup over full duplication deployment time while returning an appropriate SID-protected executable

Offline cost: guided search average ~3500 minutes and representative SID evaluation ~880 minutes across applications, while MLP training is negligible (seconds); these are one-time per application costs

In a case study of high SDC-prone inputs, Protego substantially outperforms baseline SID: average coverage loss 6.41% for Protego versus 22.89% for static SID, showing particular strength when inputs activate previously unprotected vulnerable regions
